Quick Start

Source: vignettes/quickstart.Rmd
quickstart.Rmd

Install flaiR with Using remotes

flaiR is built on top of the reticulate package and incorporates key functions to access the core features of FlairNLP, returning data in a tidy and efficient data.table. The installation consists of two parts: First, install Python 3.7 or higher, and thereticulate package in R. Additionally, you’ll also need Anaconda to assist reticulate in setting up your Python environment, as well as enabling your RStudio to identify the environment.

System Requirement:

  • Python (>= 3.7.0)

  • R (>= 3.6.3)

  • Anaconda (optional)

install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("davidycliao/flaiR", force = TRUE)
library(flaiR)
 flaiR: An R Wrapper for Accessing Flair NLP Tagging Features      
 Python : 3.11

If this is your first time using Python-related packages in like flair with R (flaiR), it’s highly likely that you haven’t yet installed a Conda environment. When you are loading flaiR in R, it automatically goes through two steps. First, it creates a conda environment called r-reticulate, during which you’ll see a lot of messages related to the installation of the Python environment. Afterward, you will see the message “Virtual environment ‘r-reticulate’ successfully created.” Next, you will be prompted to confirm whether or not you want to use r-reticulate. Enter “Yes,” and it will automatically install flair via your conda enviroment in Python.

Note: It’s worth noting that using the transformer-based pre-trained model from FlairNLP can be computationally intensive. Therefore, implementing parallel computing in R is recommended to enhance the performance of the tasks.

 

Quick Use

Tagging Parts-of-Speech with Flair Models

Load the pretrained model “pos-fast”. For more pretrained models, see https://flairnlp.github.io/docs/tutorial-basics/part-of-speech-tagging#-in-english.

texts <- c("UCD is one of the best universities in Ireland.",
           "UCD has a good campus but is very far from my apartment in Dublin.",
           "Essex is famous for social science research.",
           "Essex is not in the Russell Group, but it is famous for political science research and in 1994 Group.",
           "TCD is the oldest university in Ireland.",
           "TCD is similar to Oxford.")

doc_ids <- c("doc1", "doc2", "doc3", "doc4", "doc5", "doc6")
library(flaiR)
tagger_pos <- load_tagger_pos("pos-fast")
#> 2023-09-20 20:43:49,538 SequenceTagger predicts: Dictionary with 53 tags: <unk>, O, UH, ,, VBD, PRP, VB, PRP$, NN, RB, ., DT, JJ, VBP, VBG, IN, CD, NNS, NNP, WRB, VBZ, WDT, CC, TO, MD, VBN, WP, :, RP, EX, JJR, FW, XX, HYPH, POS, RBR, JJS, PDT, NNPS, RBS, AFX, WP$, -LRB-, -RRB-, ``, '', LS, $, SYM, ADD
results <- get_pos(texts, doc_ids, tagger_pos)
#> Warning: Internet connection issue. Please check your network settings.
head(results, n = 10)
#>     doc_id token_id text_id        token tag precision
#>  1:   doc1        0      NA          UCD NNP    0.9967
#>  2:   doc1        1      NA           is VBZ    1.0000
#>  3:   doc1        2      NA          one  CD    0.9993
#>  4:   doc1        3      NA           of  IN    1.0000
#>  5:   doc1        4      NA          the  DT    1.0000
#>  6:   doc1        5      NA         best JJS    0.9988
#>  7:   doc1        6      NA universities NNS    0.9997
#>  8:   doc1        7      NA           in  IN    1.0000
#>  9:   doc1        8      NA      Ireland NNP    1.0000
#> 10:   doc1        9      NA            .   .    0.9998

Tagging Entities with Flair Models

Load the pretrained model “ner”. For more pretrained models, see https://flairnlp.github.io/docs/tutorial-basics/tagging-entities.

library(flaiR)
tagger_ner <- load_tagger_ner("ner")
#> 2023-09-20 21:00:56,763 SequenceTagger predicts: Dictionary with 20 tags: <unk>, O, S-ORG, S-MISC, B-PER, E-PER, S-LOC, B-ORG, E-ORG, I-PER, S-PER, B-MISC, I-MISC, E-MISC, I-ORG, B-LOC, E-LOC, I-LOC, <START>, <STOP>
results <- get_entities(texts, doc_ids, tagger_ner)
#> Warning: Internet connection issue. Please check your network settings.
head(results, n = 10)
#>     doc_id        entity tag
#>  1:   doc1           UCD ORG
#>  2:   doc1       Ireland LOC
#>  3:   doc2           UCD ORG
#>  4:   doc2        Dublin LOC
#>  5:   doc3         Essex ORG
#>  6:   doc4         Essex ORG
#>  7:   doc4 Russell Group ORG
#>  8:   doc5           TCD ORG
#>  9:   doc5       Ireland LOC
#> 10:   doc6           TCD ORG

Tagging Sentiment

Load the pretrained model “sentiment”. The pre-trained models of “sentiment”, “sentiment-fast”, and “de-offensive-language” are currently available. For more pretrained models, see https://flairnlp.github.io/docs/tutorial-basics/tagging-sentiment.

library(flaiR)
tagger_sent <- load_tagger_sentiments("sentiment")
results <- get_sentiments(texts, doc_ids, tagger_sent)
#> Warning: Internet connection issue. Please check your network settings.
head(results, n = 10)
#>    doc_id sentiment     score
#> 1:   doc1  POSITIVE 0.9970598
#> 2:   doc2  NEGATIVE 0.8472336
#> 3:   doc3  POSITIVE 0.9928006
#> 4:   doc4  POSITIVE 0.9901405
#> 5:   doc5  POSITIVE 0.9952670
#> 6:   doc6  POSITIVE 0.9291794

 

How to Contribute

Contributions in the form of comments, code suggestions, and tutorial examples are very welcome. Please note that the flaiR is released with the Contributor Code of Conduct. By contributing to this project, you agree to abide by its terms.
